trans-unit.source: Get Started with Fleet on CoreOS on Azure
trans-unit.target: Get Started with Fleet on CoreOS on Azure

trans-unit.source: Provides basic examples of using Fleet and Docker on a CoreOS Linux virtual machine on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Provides basic examples of using Fleet and Docker on a CoreOS Linux virtual machine on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Get Started with Fleet on CoreOS on Azure
trans-unit.target: Get Started with Fleet on CoreOS on Azure

trans-unit.source: This article gives you two quick examples of using <link><linkText>fleet</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Docker</linkText><title></title></link> to run applications on a cluster of [CoreOS] virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: This article gives you two quick examples of using <link><linkText>fleet</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Docker</linkText><title></title></link> to run applications on a cluster of [CoreOS] virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: To use these examples, first set up a three-node CoreOS cluster as described in [How to Use CoreOS on Azure].
trans-unit.target: To use these examples, first set up a three-node CoreOS cluster as described in [How to Use CoreOS on Azure].

trans-unit.source: Having done that, you'll understand the very basic elements of CoreOS deployments and have a working cluster and client computer.
trans-unit.target: Having done that, you'll understand the very basic elements of CoreOS deployments and have a working cluster and client computer.

trans-unit.source: We'll use exactly the same cluster name in these examples.
trans-unit.target: We'll use exactly the same cluster name in these examples.

trans-unit.source: Also, these examples assume you're using your local Linux host to run your fleetctl commands.
trans-unit.target: Also, these examples assume you're using your local Linux host to run your fleetctl commands.

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Example 1: Hello World with Docker<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Example 1: Hello World with Docker<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Here is a simple "Hello World" application that runs in a single Docker container.
trans-unit.target: Here is a simple "Hello World" application that runs in a single Docker container.

trans-unit.source: This uses the [busybox Docker Hub image].
trans-unit.target: This uses the [busybox Docker Hub image].

trans-unit.source: On your Linux client computer, use your favorite text editor to create the following systemd unit file and name it helloworld.service.
trans-unit.target: On your Linux client computer, use your favorite text editor to create the following systemd unit file and name it helloworld.service.

trans-unit.source: (For details about the syntax, see [Unit Files].)
trans-unit.target: (For details about the syntax, see [Unit Files].)

trans-unit.source: Now connect to the CoreOS cluster and start the unit by running the following fleetctl command.
trans-unit.target: Now connect to the CoreOS cluster and start the unit by running the following fleetctl command.

trans-unit.source: The output shows that the unit is started and where it's located.
trans-unit.target: The output shows that the unit is started and where it's located.

trans-unit.source: To run your remote fleetctl commands without the --tunnel parameter, optionally set the FLEETCTL_TUNNEL environment variable to tunnel the requests.
trans-unit.target: To run your remote fleetctl commands without the --tunnel parameter, optionally set the FLEETCTL_TUNNEL environment variable to tunnel the requests.

trans-unit.source: For example: export FLEETCTL_TUNNEL=coreos-cluster.cloudapp.net:22.
trans-unit.target: For example: export FLEETCTL_TUNNEL=coreos-cluster.cloudapp.net:22.

trans-unit.source: You can connect to the container to see the output of the service:
trans-unit.target: You can connect to the container to see the output of the service:

trans-unit.source: To clean up, stop and unload the unit.
trans-unit.target: To clean up, stop and unload the unit.

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Example 2: Highly available Apache server<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Example 2: Highly available Apache server<html></html>

trans-unit.source: One advantage of using CoreOS, Docker, and fleet is that it's easy to run services in a highly available manner.
trans-unit.target: One advantage of using CoreOS, Docker, and fleet is that it's easy to run services in a highly available manner.

trans-unit.source: In this example you'll deploy a service that consists of three identical containers running the Apache web server.
trans-unit.target: In this example you'll deploy a service that consists of three identical containers running the Apache web server.

trans-unit.source: The containers will run on the three VMs in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: The containers will run on the three VMs in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: This example is similar to one in [Launching containers with fleet] and uses the [CoreOS Apache Docker Hub image].
trans-unit.target: This example is similar to one in [Launching containers with fleet] and uses the [CoreOS Apache Docker Hub image].

trans-unit.source: To run the highly available Apache server, you'll need to configure a load-balanced HTTP endpoint on the virtual machines (public port 80, private port 80).
trans-unit.target: To run the highly available Apache server, you'll need to configure a load-balanced HTTP endpoint on the virtual machines (public port 80, private port 80).

trans-unit.source: You can do this after creating the CoreOS cluster, using the Azure portal or azure vm endpoint command.
trans-unit.target: You can do this after creating the CoreOS cluster, using the Azure portal or azure vm endpoint command.

trans-unit.source: See [Configure a load-balanced set] for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [Configure a load-balanced set] for more information.

trans-unit.source: On your client computer, use your favorite text editor to create a systemd template unit file, named apache@.service.
trans-unit.target: On your client computer, use your favorite text editor to create a systemd template unit file, named apache@.service.

trans-unit.source: You'll use that template to launch three separate instances, named apache@1.service, apache@2.service, and apache@3.service:
trans-unit.target: You'll use that template to launch three separate instances, named apache@1.service, apache@2.service, and apache@3.service:

trans-unit.source: The X-Conflicts attribute tells CoreOS that only one instance of this container can be run on a given CoreOS host.
trans-unit.target: The X-Conflicts attribute tells CoreOS that only one instance of this container can be run on a given CoreOS host.

trans-unit.source: For details see [Unit Files].
trans-unit.target: For details see [Unit Files].

trans-unit.source: Now start the unit instances on the CoreOS cluster.
trans-unit.target: Now start the unit instances on the CoreOS cluster.

trans-unit.source: You should see that they're running on three different machines:
trans-unit.target: You should see that they're running on three different machines:

trans-unit.source: To reach the Apache server running on one of the units, send a simple request to the cloud service hosting the CoreOS cluster.
trans-unit.target: To reach the Apache server running on one of the units, send a simple request to the cloud service hosting the CoreOS cluster.

trans-unit.source: curl http://coreos-cluster.cloudapp.net
trans-unit.target: curl http://coreos-cluster.cloudapp.net

trans-unit.source: You'll see default text returned from the Apache server similar to:
trans-unit.target: You'll see default text returned from the Apache server similar to:

trans-unit.source: You can try shutting down one or more virtual machines in your cluster to verify that the Apache service continues to run.
trans-unit.target: You can try shutting down one or more virtual machines in your cluster to verify that the Apache service continues to run.

trans-unit.source: When done, stop and unload units.
trans-unit.target: When done, stop and unload units.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: You can try doing more with your three-node CoreOS cluster on Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can try doing more with your three-node CoreOS cluster on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Explore how to create more complex clusters and use Docker and create more interesting applications by reading [Tim Park's CoreOS Tutorial], [Patrick Chanezon's CoreOS Tutorial], [Docker] documentation, and the [CoreOS Overview].
trans-unit.target: Explore how to create more complex clusters and use Docker and create more interesting applications by reading [Tim Park's CoreOS Tutorial], [Patrick Chanezon's CoreOS Tutorial], [Docker] documentation, and the [CoreOS Overview].

trans-unit.source: To get started with Fleet and CoreOS in Azure Resource Manager, try this <link><linkText>quickstart template</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To get started with Fleet and CoreOS in Azure Resource Manager, try this <link><linkText>quickstart template</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: See [Linux and Open-Source Computing on Azure] for more on using open-source environments on Linux VMs in Azure.
trans-unit.target: See [Linux and Open-Source Computing on Azure] for more on using open-source environments on Linux VMs in Azure.
